_prev_prog_3.Description: Grapery Cold Storage has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with California's Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements). At the Federal level, (Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189 Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials), Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Grapery has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Grapery, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Grapery has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which has the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name           | Process Chemical          | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration    Anhydrous Ammonia           33,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized t

he program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



Grapery operates a table grape cold storage facility in Shafter, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

(7) Precoolers

(5) Cold Storage Rooms

Refrigerated Hallway



The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation. All control valve groups are mounted on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within a refrigeration machinery room or directly outside near the machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:

Machinery Room

(1) FRICK Model RWFII-134-H Compressor

(2) FRICK Model RWFII-222-H Compressors

(1) 30" Dia. x 6'-0" Long Thermosyphon Vessel

(1) Frick Model XLP2 1236-2036-2 Condenser

(1) 54" Dia. x 12'-0" Long Main Suction Accumulator

(1) 20" Dia. x 4'-0" Long Transfer Vessel

(1) 96" Dia. x 38'-0" Long High Pressure Receiver

(1) Ammonia Diffusion Tank

(1) Emergency Pressure Control System

(1) Guntner Model GGHN 050.2D/26 Air Unit for the Mechanical Room

(2) Guntner Model AGBK 050.1B/27 Air Units for the Electrical Room

(1) Frick Model LZW-115 Plate Heat Exchanger

(1) 20" Dia. x 5'-0" High Suction Accumulator Vessel



Air Cooling Evaporators

(14) Plate Fin Stainless Steel Tube Bunker Coils designed for the facility's (7) precool rooms - 42" deep x 26" high x 25'-0" long.

(20) Plate Fin Stainless Steel Tube Bunker Coils designed for the facility's (7) precool rooms - 42" deep x 22" high x 25'-0" long.



Each Standard Precool Room

(1) 36" Dia. x 6'-10" High Accumulator

(4) Room Fans. 42" Diameter fans

(4)

Tunnel Fans. 42" Diameter fans



The Super Precooler (PC-4)

(1) 36" Dia. x 6'-10" High Accumulator

(4) Room Fans. 48" Diameter fans

(4) Tunnel Fans. 48" Diameter fans



31?F Cold Storage Rooms

(2) 30" Dia. x 7'-0" High Horizontal Accumulators

(8) Room Fans. 36" Diameter fans



32?F Hallway Zones

(5) Guntner Model AXGHN 071.2H/26WNL51 Ceiling Unit



The system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator mounted behind the bunker wall. From the accumulators, cold liquid ammonia is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The ammonia vapor is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to the main suction accumulator on the machinery room roof.  From the main suction accumulator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the thermosyphon vessel and then to the high pressure receiver.



Grapery was built in 2014-2015 by California Controlled Atmosphere. The facility was built in accordance with the 2010 California Mechanical Code, 2010 California Fire Code, and ANSI/IIAR 2-2008 Addendum B. The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent ammonia gas to the diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. Each entrance to the machinery room contains emergency refrigeration and ventilation controls for use during an emergency situation.



The ammonia system at Grapery consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are

interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Grapery is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Grapery has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Grapery facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 33000 lbs. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Grapery has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Grapery's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38



Strategically, w

e will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Grapery has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Grapery continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Grapery's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Grapery's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Grapery has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Grapery has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Grapery now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Grapery employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Grapery will continue to maintain ov
erall plant worker and public safety.
